Deconstruction Simulator is, in terms of gameplay, a simple game. 

You accept contracts, most often to demolish a given house, from which the contractor often wants you to give load some of the items still in the house into their car, with the rest being free for you to take back to your warehouse. 

These items you then sell via customer orders, to earn some extra money. Though you never know just what the orders are going to want. And they refresh daily (But I do feel like the game goes out of its way to generate orders for at least some of the items you do actually have, not completely random-like)

...Or you can just recycle them, if your warehouse's full, but then you will not be getting any money for those.

Aside from big items (And small ones, that you pack away in boxes that you bring back), your mission is to... Deconstruct, the house.

The approach you choose is up to you. Either you can pick it apart, piece by piece (Or rather, wall by wall and plank by plank), which is painfully slow, but you do get to keep the materials, or you can pull out your trusty old sledgehammer, and mash all the walls to pieces (Then also clean up the pieces, and bring back the bags of trash for recycling, for which you do actually get some money back this time!)

Slowly, as you finish more contracts and orders, you build up your reputation, unlocking permits that let you take on bigger, more luxurious homes and houses, that take longer to demolish, and contain more furniture and items for you to (voluntarily, up to you) take back and sell. 

###################################

Okay, so now that you know what the game's flow is like. what are it's ups and downs?
+ The game's physics are fun, making the demolition satisfying
+ Many different houses to take down
+ Easy to pick up, casual, satisfying gameplay

- Can be pretty tedious, with all the furniture, and all the little items, I get easily overwhelmed by the amount of work each house takes.

I really like this game so far, but I can't recommend it in it's current state. I hope the bugs detailed below are fixed soon and I will amend my review afterward. Dev communication so far has been excellent in both the Steam forums and Discord (though I'd like to see a known-issues list), so I do have hope.

Unfortunately, there is a bug which is completely killing my enjoyment where items can despawn when you leave the job site. The game is designed such that you have to leave and return multiple times in order to finish unless, maybe, you destroy literally everything, so I can't see any way to avoid this unless you are much better than I am at figuring out what will fit in the van by eyeballing it.

The first time this happened to me, another player let me know on Discord they had previously reported this issue (he had an early access key) and it seemed to happen to items you left near the delivery van. However, after starting over (I had lost a customer-requested item and didn't want to lose the reputation), I had multiple items disappear from inside the house. Brick pallets are apparently especially susceptible to this, though I had at least four other different types of items disappear, so it's not limited to them.

There are a couple other more minor bugs related to game settings. When I quit the game, all of my settings were reset and I had to redo them. Other people report this happening whenever they try to confirm the settings with the hotkey. (The workaround is to just exit the settings menu and select to save them that way instead.) Also, some people have reported that various difficulty settings (which are not modifiable after the prologue) are resetting mid-game.

People also report progress-stopping bugs in the prologue and crashing, but I didn't experience them.

This isn't a bug per se, but I'd also really like a way to rotate items in all three dimensions. In particular, there is no way to lay an item flat. For example, drywall can either be set down at an extreme angle or at a low angle, but if you want to slide it in into the truck on top of a refrigerator, you're out of luck. With as much work as they seem to have put into the collision boxes and physics, and with van-tetris being kind of fun in general, it's strange how difficult it is just to put something into a space which is obviously large enough to accommodate it. It would also be nice if there was a way to "nudge" items without having to pick them up and completely reposition them. Also, items tend to bounce around like they're made of Styrofoam when you place them too close to the van walls, which is strange since the game won't let you place things where there are collisions.

Beyond that, I was really enjoying the game so far, though I was only on the first mission post-tutorial. Disassembling items is a bit annoying and that's a little surprising since it seems like the optimal way to play in the early game is already to destroy almost everything and thus bypass the tools. This is because the starter van is just far too small for anything else to make sense due to fuel costs unless the job site is extremely close to the warehouse. This may change later with a large truck, faster tools and more expensive items, but I'm not there yet.

Destroying stuff is fun in general, though it does feel like it takes maybe too many hits with the sledge. This may be something that gets upgraded later, I'm not sure.

When picking up items like wood planks or bricks, and when placing them onto pallets, i would like to be able to hold down the button instead of having to press the button repeatedly. My RSI will thank you for making this change. :D

The warehouse is a really cool idea and it's fun to store things there. I don't know yet how I feel about the "orders" system where you look for people wanting things you have. It feels a little convoluted and game-y. I'd rather hold an auction or build a house or something.

Performance is great for me with a 3060ti and 5600x. With high settings, default FoV and DLSS 4 (the game comes with DLSS 3 but I updated it via DLSS Swapper) DLSS: Balanced is giving me 55-65 FPS in 1440p, which I'm doubling to 110 with Lossless Scaling while still having some GPU room to spare. I haven't noticed any hitching, though I wouldn't expect to since the game takes place in relatively small areas with a loading screen between them.

I'd also like to note that I think the price is extremely reasonable and much less than the community had been expecting pre-launch. If the aforementioned bugs are resolved, this is an easy game to recommend.

I originally bought this game, in the blind, because I love Ship Graveyard Simulator 2 so much, and was hoping this would be a building version of that. I assume I'm not alone in that, but am sad to report that this is not that.

After a frustrating Tutorial experience, I decided to 100% the first level before writing my review, and ultimately have decided that this game is more not fun than fun, hence the thumbs down. Will you like this game? Maybe. I don't know. I'll detail below what the game entails, so you can decide if it sounds fun or not.

First, this is not a Deconstruction Simulator game. At least not primarily. That comes like fourth.

1st - It's a van loading/unloading simulator - Every plank, every piece of drywall, every piece of furniture, every bucket of small items, etc. must be manually loaded into your van, in a maddening game of wobbly-physics Tetris. And then, when something is sticking out just a little too far, and you try to close the doors, they will almost close, and then fly back open, so you can play Tetris some more. Then, once you finally get the load in and doors closed (of which you will have many many runs/loads per job), you get to unload everything in your warehouse! Every plank, every piece of drywall, every piece of furniture, etc. I hate this. Then, when it comes time to sell off everything you've stockpiled, yay, you get to load it all up again in the buyer's van! So you've now loaded/unloaded every single piece of everything, no less than three times, before you can get it out of your life. Did I mention I hate this?

2nd - It's an inventory management game - Very few games handle inventory management well, and this is not one of them. It's usually a necessary bummer, but this game tries to make it the secondary game loop. Once you get everything to your warehouse, you have to sort it all into the correct shelves, like a HomeDepot worker stocking the lumber yard. Then, once my warehouse was full (after just one job), I couldn't sell any of it off because I still didn't have all of the items in any of the available client orders, so I guess I was just expected to start the second job with a full warehouse and start dumping stuff anywhere there was space, since my shelves were full?

3rd - It's an IKEA furniture disassembly simulator - You spend more time taking apart all the different furniture pieces than you do the house. I will say, it is very satisfying how each piece of furniture auto-packages itself into a new IKEA box after disassembly.

4th - It's a deconstruction simulator, which should really only be called a wall removal simulator - The ceiling and floors are just bashed with a hammer and thrown in the trash. It's only the walls that are taken apart and salvaged.

Lastly, this game has chosen punishment over reward. It charges you for gas. It charges you rent. When you complete a level, you don't get paid (immediately), but rather you invoice the customer and have to wait. If you break something you shouldn't, you get docked for it (why not instead reward a player who doesn't damage anything?). This realism isn't fun. I play games to NOT think about bills. Don't give me game bills.



Wish List
- Let me carry more than 1 piece of drywall at a time. Loading/Unloading a stack of 50 sheets (3 times), one-by-one, is not a fun game mechanic.
- You currently have to wiggle your mouse to use many of the tools. I don't want to wiggle my mouse, I want to click once and hold. This isn't a VR game.
- Let me just sell off the stuff I salvaged. What am I supposed to do when the warehouse is full and there aren't any fullfillable orders?
- Let me just chuck everything into the truck. If there must be a capacity system (volume? weight?) so be it, but I never ever want to stack anything in these ridiculous physics simulators. I hate it. It is not fun. It is what your game is, and shouldn't be.
- The game runs hotter than an American Eagle jeans ad. Needs more optimization.

The game, at its core, has three issues that hold it back more than even the glitches.
 
The first might be a minor or major issue depending on who you are. While the beginning hints at some kind of story or narrative to encourage you to continue growing your business, this kind of just vanishes after the tutorial. While this isn't a deal breaker, it does make any failures of the game's other systems stand out all the more blatantly.

The second is the gameplay loop. The overall flow is: Go to site, collect as many materials/valuables as you can, break everything else, clean up, go home, sell what you brought back. The primary issue with the loop is that the "sell what you brought back" portion lags far slower that you are going to be getting materials and valuables. You sell the items in the form of requests that are fully random both in how close to full value the item is, how many items they want, and what kind they want. That means that you will VERY quickly accumulate a ton of inventory and seriously struggle to get rid of anything.

To clarify why this becomes a problem, let's say you treat a home like a Buffalo and carefully break down everything you can and bring back everything you can as I started doing early on.  If you get unlucky, you might never seem to get a request for lumber and even if you do it will only be for one particular kind meaning you will accumulate a ton of one specific size that you can never seem to get rid of. All of the items you can bring back and sell have this problem and you could go several in game days of nothing only to have one order asking for a ton of stuff but they just HAPPEN to be asking for the ONE thing you don't have and there's no assurance that the next few contracts you do will have what they are asking for. So you just end up accumulating more junk hoping desperately you are hording the right stuff.

The third is probably the biggest disappointment: Lack of hazards. Hardspace: Shipbreaker is probably the abject best example of how to handle games focused on deconstruction and has a feature that easily puts it ahead of the rest are hazards. As you are working, you actively have to consider what you are tearing apart and how. Without hazards, games centered on deconstruction inevitably just boil down to a very monotonous cycle where you smash stuff until it falls over. There's no fear of being under the roof as it collapses, no pipes you need to close off, and, heck, you can literally smash the power bank that provides the building electricity hard enough to make it explode into sparks and nothing happens.

The third point is honestly the biggest elephant in the room for me. Ironically, Ship Graveyard Simulator 1 had this exact same problem and even the sequel doesn't really utilize hazards enough to be a huge challenge. As it stands, the most efficient method of playing this game is to recover any item people want, smash the two edge planks holding walls up until all of the walls come down, pack up the mess, and leave. Without any risk to smashing buildings apart like a maniac, the game just turns into one of those rage rooms where you smash stuff to let off steam.

Great fun in the flesh. Digitally, it gets dull very quickly when you realize everything you smash just feels the same.

There's some 200.000 games on Steam right now. You could be exploring faraway galaxies, leading vast armies, saving a beautiful dragon from a horrible princess, you could be building magnificent cities, or perhaps entire civilizations that will stand the test of time. You could be securing the future of your royal dynasty by getting to know your sister better. You could be a master assassin, or an ancient vampire, heck you could run around and cause mischief as a goat. Either of those would be more fun than what the devs, appropriately named Incubator, are expecting you to spend your limited time on this planet on. 

This game lures you in with a promise of explosive action - something that could help lower your cortisol levels after a stressful day job. Instead, it offers an exciting opportunity to do a second job in your free time. Indeed, the Destruction tag in this mostly refers to your sanity. You get half a dozen tools in this game - screwdrivers, saws, you name it. And all of them but one you can upgrade many times. The one you can't is the sledgehammer. You nominally have it, yes, but the game goes out of its way to discourage your using it. That's because it wants you to spent 10 minutes carefully dismantling a wardrobe - one screw at a time - because you can then sell it for more than the entire contract's worth... And the wrecking ball? Well, it costs $600 to rent one, when the contract to wreck the house pays... that's right, $600. Mic drop.

Sadly this game appears to have enough content to fill a demo and not much more. No real complexity or difficulty curve to speak up. The unlocks for new tools are not rewarding or particularly helpful, slightly father disassembly of furniture or a technically larger vehicle that isn't much more helpful because of bad physics. The secondary RNG around selling the components you optionally gather from demolished houses is another premise that seems fun but works poorly.

Dev communication so far has been excellent in both the Steam forums and Discord (though I'd like to see a known-issues list), so I do have hope.

Unfortunately, there is a bug which is completely killing my enjoyment where items can despawn when you leave the job site. The game is designed such that you have to leave and return multiple times in order to finish unless, maybe, you destroy literally everything, so I can't see any way to avoid this unless you are much better than I am at figuring out what will fit in the van by eyeballing it.

The first time this happened to me, another player let me know on Discord they had previously reported this issue (he had an early access key) and it seemed to happen to items you left near the delivery van. However, after starting over (I had lost a customer-requested item and didn't want to lose the reputation), I had multiple items disappear from inside the house. Brick pallets are apparently especially susceptible to this, though I had at least four other different types of items disappear, so it's not limited to them.

There are a couple other more minor bugs related to game settings. When I quit the game, all of my settings were reset and I had to redo them. Other people report this happening whenever they try to confirm the settings with the hotkey. (The workaround is to just exit the settings menu and select to save them that way instead.) Also, some people have reported that various difficulty settings (which are not modifiable after the prologue) are resetting mid-game.

People also report progress-stopping bugs in the prologue and crashing, but I didn't experience them.

This isn't a bug per se, but I'd also really like a way to rotate items in all three dimensions. In particular, there is no way to lay an item flat. For example, drywall can either be set down at an extreme angle or at a low angle, but if you want to slide it in into the truck on top of a refrigerator, you're out of luck. With as much work as they seem to have put into the collision boxes and physics, and with van-tetris being kind of fun in general, it's strange how difficult it is just to put something into a space which is obviously large enough to accommodate it. It would also be nice if there was a way to "nudge" items without having to pick them up and completely reposition them. Also, items tend to bounce around like they're made of Styrofoam when you place them too close to the van walls, which is strange since the game won't let you place things where there are collisions.

Beyond that, I was really enjoying the game so far, though I was only on the first mission post-tutorial. Disassembling items is a bit annoying and that's a little surprising since it seems like the optimal way to play in the early game is already to destroy almost everything and thus bypass the tools. This is because the starter van is just far too small for anything else to make sense due to fuel costs unless the job site is extremely close to the warehouse. This may change later with a large truck, faster tools and more expensive items, but I'm not there yet.

Destroying stuff is fun in general, though it does feel like it takes maybe too many hits with the sledge. This may be something that gets upgraded later, I'm not sure.

When picking up items like wood planks or bricks, and when placing them onto pallets, i would like to be able to hold down the button instead of having to press the button repeatedly. My RSI will thank you for making this change. :D

The warehouse is a really cool idea and it's fun to store things there. I don't know yet how I feel about the "orders" system where you look for people wanting things you have. It feels a little convoluted and game-y. I'd rather hold an auction or build a house or something.

Performance is great for me with a 3060ti and 5600x. With high settings, default FoV and DLSS 4 (the game comes with DLSS 3 but I updated it via DLSS Swapper) DLSS: Balanced is giving me 55-65 FPS in 1440p, which I'm doubling to 110 with Lossless Scaling while still having some GPU room to spare. I haven't noticed any hitching, though I wouldn't expect to since the game takes place in relatively small areas with a loading screen between them.

I'd also like to note that I think the price is extremely reasonable and much less than the community had been expecting pre-launch. If the aforementioned bugs are resolved, this is an easy game to recommend.

I originally bought this game, in the blind, because I love Ship Graveyard Simulator 2 so much, and was hoping this would be a building version of that. I assume I'm not alone in that, but am sad to report that this is not that.

After a frustrating Tutorial experience, I decided to 100% the first level before writing my review, and ultimately have decided that this game is more not fun than fun, hence the thumbs down. Will you like this game? Maybe. I don't know. I'll detail below what the game entails, so you can decide if it sounds fun or not.

First, this is not a Deconstruction Simulator game. At least not primarily. That comes like fourth.

1st - It's a van loading/unloading simulator - Every plank, every piece of drywall, every piece of furniture, every bucket of small items, etc. must be manually loaded into your van, in a maddening game of wobbly-physics Tetris. And then, when something is sticking out just a little too far, and you try to close the doors, they will almost close, and then fly back open, so you can play Tetris some more. Then, once you finally get the load in and doors closed (of which you will have many many runs/loads per job), you get to unload everything in your warehouse! Every plank, every piece of drywall, every piece of furniture, etc. I hate this. Then, when it comes time to sell off everything you've stockpiled, yay, you get to load it all up again in the buyer's van! So you've now loaded/unloaded every single piece of everything, no less than three times, before you can get it out of your life. Did I mention I hate this?

2nd - It's an inventory management game - Very few games handle inventory management well, and this is not one of them. It's usually a necessary bummer, but this game tries to make it the secondary game loop. Once you get everything to your warehouse, you have to sort it all into the correct shelves, like a HomeDepot worker stocking the lumber yard. Then, once my warehouse was full (after just one job), I couldn't sell any of it off because I still didn't have all of the items in any of the available client orders, so I guess I was just expected to start the second job with a full warehouse and start dumping stuff anywhere there was space, since my shelves were full?

3rd - It's an IKEA furniture disassembly simulator - You spend more time taking apart all the different furniture pieces than you do the house. I will say, it is very satisfying how each piece of furniture auto-packages itself into a new IKEA box after disassembly.

4th - It's a deconstruction simulator, which should really only be called a wall removal simulator - The ceiling and floors are just bashed with a hammer and thrown in the trash. It's only the walls that are taken apart and salvaged.

Lastly, this game has chosen punishment over reward. It charges you for gas. It charges you rent. When you complete a level, you don't get paid (immediately), but rather you invoice the customer and have to wait. If you break something you shouldn't, you get docked for it (why not instead reward a player who doesn't damage anything?). This realism isn't fun. I play games to NOT think about bills. Don't give me game bills.



Wish List
- Let me carry more than 1 piece of drywall at a time. Loading/Unloading a stack of 50 sheets (3 times), one-by-one, is not a fun game mechanic.
- You currently have to wiggle your mouse to use many of the tools. I don't want to wiggle my mouse, I want to click once and hold. This isn't a VR game.
- Let me just sell off the stuff I salvaged. What am I supposed to do when the warehouse is full and there aren't any fullfillable orders?
- Let me just chuck everything into the truck. If there must be a capacity system (volume? weight?) so be it, but I never ever want to stack anything in these ridiculous physics simulators. I hate it. It is not fun. It is what your game is, and shouldn't be.
- The game runs hotter than an American Eagle jeans ad. Needs more optimization.

The game, at its core, has three issues that hold it back more than even the glitches.
 
The first might be a minor or major issue depending on who you are. While the beginning hints at some kind of story or narrative to encourage you to continue growing your business, this kind of just vanishes after the tutorial. While this isn't a deal breaker, it does make any failures of the game's other systems stand out all the more blatantly.

The second is the gameplay loop. The overall flow is: Go to site, collect as many materials/valuables as you can, break everything else, clean up, go home, sell what you brought back. The primary issue with the loop is that the "sell what you brought back" portion lags far slower that you are going to be getting materials and valuables. You sell the items in the form of requests that are fully random both in how close to full value the item is, how many items they want, and what kind they want. That means that you will VERY quickly accumulate a ton of inventory and seriously struggle to get rid of anything.

To clarify why this becomes a problem, let's say you treat a home like a Buffalo and carefully break down everything you can and bring back everything you can as I started doing early on.  If you get unlucky, you might never seem to get a request for lumber and even if you do it will only be for one particular kind meaning you will accumulate a ton of one specific size that you can never seem to get rid of. All of the items you can bring back and sell have this problem and you could go several in game days of nothing only to have one order asking for a ton of stuff but they just HAPPEN to be asking for the ONE thing you don't have and there's no assurance that the next few contracts you do will have what they are asking for. So you just end up accumulating more junk hoping desperately you are hording the right stuff.

The third is probably the biggest disappointment: Lack of hazards. Hardspace: Shipbreaker is probably the abject best example of how to handle games focused on deconstruction and has a feature that easily puts it ahead of the rest are hazards. As you are working, you actively have to consider what you are tearing apart and how. Without hazards, games centered on deconstruction inevitably just boil down to a very monotonous cycle where you smash stuff until it falls over. There's no fear of being under the roof as it collapses, no pipes you need to close off, and, heck, you can literally smash the power bank that provides the building electricity hard enough to make it explode into sparks and nothing happens.

The third point is honestly the biggest elephant in the room for me. Ironically, Ship Graveyard Simulator 1 had this exact same problem and even the sequel doesn't really utilize hazards enough to be a huge challenge. As it stands, the most efficient method of playing this game is to recover any item people want, smash the two edge planks holding walls up until all of the walls come down, pack up the mess, and leave. Without any risk to smashing buildings apart like a maniac, the game just turns into one of those rage rooms where you smash stuff to let off steam.

Great fun in the flesh. Digitally, it gets dull very quickly when you realize everything you smash just feels the same.

There's some 200.000 games on Steam right now. You could be exploring faraway galaxies, leading vast armies, saving a beautiful dragon from a horrible princess, you could be building magnificent cities, or perhaps entire civilizations that will stand the test of time. You could be securing the future of your royal dynasty by getting to know your sister better. You could be a master assassin, or an ancient vampire, heck you could run around and cause mischief as a goat. Either of those would be more fun than what the devs, appropriately named Incubator, are expecting you to spend your limited time on this planet on. 

This game lures you in with a promise of explosive action - something that could help lower your cortisol levels after a stressful day job. Instead, it offers an exciting opportunity to do a second job in your free time. Indeed, the Destruction tag in this mostly refers to your sanity. You get half a dozen tools in this game - screwdrivers, saws, you name it. And all of them but one you can upgrade many times. The one you can't is the sledgehammer. You nominally have it, yes, but the game goes out of its way to discourage your using it. That's because it wants you to spent 10 minutes carefully dismantling a wardrobe - one screw at a time - because you can then sell it for more than the entire contract's worth... And the wrecking ball? Well, it costs $600 to rent one, when the contract to wreck the house pays... that's right, $600. Mic drop.
